LOL,....yes, that is a whole other story,...it currently takes 4+ hours to run our entire suite.  We use Mock objects, so that helps,...but we don't use them everywhere.  We also utilize "TestAll" tests, so that helps get you to a scope somewhere between one and all.

We don't run into this often,...but it does happen, and I have asked myself "Isn't there an easier way to find all the tests that might be affected by my change?"

-------------- Original message -------------- 
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@c... wrote:
> My problem is usually along the lines of: I make changes to classA, 
> which is used in classB, which is used in classC, which is tested by
> testC.  So, I have modified testA, which directly tests classA, but 
> don't realize that I have broken something in testC.  My solution is
> that we run nightlybuilds, and I check the errors/failures the next 
> morning to see if my code changes could have caused any of them.
> 
> It would be nice to be a little more proactive, though,...being able
> to (easily) find all the tests that are ultimately affected by my 
> code change (iterating through the workspace references until I 
> terminate at all classes that start with "Test", or that are in my 
> test branch).  I know that I can do this manually through Eclipse, 
> but it is not fun - and therefore doesn't get done.

How long does it take to run all your tests? That would be the obvious
first answer, I'd suggest.

Also, if you try to make your tests only test a single unit, that
helps a lot - and using mock objects helps there (I use EasyMock
myself). It certainly doesn't solve the problem 100%, but it's a good
start.

Jon
